presentation.runninghead: Values of fish to coastal populations in Madagascar

page.name: Subsistence fishing
page.title: Introduction
page.description:
This storyline intends to demonstrate the use of ARIES in mapping and quantifying specific values connected to an ecosystem service. In this case we concentrate on the value of fish resources to coastal population that depend on fish for sustainance.

Subsistence harvesting of ecosystem goods is critical in the developing world as well as in developed nations. Such ecosystem goods have been termed the “GDP of the poor”, since they provide employment and livelihoods for many of the world’s poor while not being monetized in traditional economic accounts like GDP. Societal dependence on subsistence fisheries, combined with overfishing, pollution, and climate change, demands sustainable management of aquatic resources.

Thanks to the support of the UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre we have developed this storyline for Madagascar, chosen because of its high rate of poverty, dependence on fisheries as a key protein source in rural communities, and prevalent deforestation-driven sedimentation and erosion, which strongly affect its coastal and marine systems.

page.name: Subsistence Use
page.title: Subsistence Use
page.description:
Benefitshed map

This map depicts our benefitshed, the result of the probabilistic modelling of the need for fish to support the livelihoods of coastal populations. Darker blues indicate a need that is higher in poorer populations that live closer to the coast. The map you are seeing is a probabilistic one, meaning that we establish the probability of needing fish for subsistence rather than the amount of fish needed per capita, which is known from socioeconomic data. You can click on the map and visualize the probability distribution in each point. The flow model you will see later determines the actual value of the fish resource, depending on the need, the quality and abundance of the resource, and the ability of accessing it by walking to the shoreline.

page.description:
Now that we have quantified the need for fish, we must model the actual provision of fish. Data about abundance of different species of fish are available for FishBase and can be used as a starting point in modeling the likely harvest. We have chosen the three most important species for subsistence in Madagascar. What you are looking at here is the abundance of ... in .... The data provided by FishBase have 0.5 degree resolution, so we need to use a coarse grid here. Yet, ARIES can automatically interpolate with the result of other models to provide better looking maps, and will compute the uncertainty related to the interpolation so that no information gets lost.
